> ...Which of these two ways would you consider, in the context of Extreme 
> Programming, to be the "Simplest Thing Which Could Possibly Work"?


I definitively stick with my approach even if it's maybe not the 
"Simplest thing which could possibly work".  But it's maybe because I 
don't stick to this principle.

In many cases, the simplest thing that works is #ifdef ... #endif (in 
C++).  Well I let you imagine how a code may look like after several 
years of #ifdef... #endif!

You can argue that you should refactor... well unless someone has a 
_real_ good reason to spend time refactoring something that works 
perfectly, he would rather do other things that don't currently work.

 > However, the specialized Assert class (i.e.-delegation) appears to be 
more

> flexible and easier to change in the future. It also seems to better communicate 
> the purpose of the new class.


If you extend the TestCase class, you can use your assertion in the 
subclass.  But you cannot use your assertion in an ExceptionTestCase, 
TestDecorator, TestSetup subclass unless you have created as specialized 
TestCase for that particular TestCase class.

My personal thoughts

-Vladimir
